Posts.Title: Good Scan Results! AmyJM cmhartley

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 04:06AM Australia wrote: Hello I am Gail. I live in Australia and have one IVF son who is 20 and studying science at uni. He is the most wonderful son and we love one another very much. I am divorced and live with my so and a housemate. Was diagnosed with early bc in April 2006 with 17 of 25 nodes positive. Did chemo and rads and supposed to be on AI's for 5 years but could not take the side effects and gave up. July 2012 had been suffering with sore back and very painful rib, also noticed I had a crackle in my breathing at night. Went on for a few months with gp thinking it was after effects of virus going around. Got to the stage where I was becoming incontinent but with no bladder infection( turned out it was caused by the calcium leaching out of my bones into bloodstream). Finally I said I think I have lung cancer and gp sent me off for x rays. To cut a long story short I was diagnosed with cancer to several areas in spine/ribs and hip. Also plural effusion and medestinal nodes around lungs with cancer. I spent several weeks in hospital and had rads to most important areas, 3 effusions before finally having the talc done to lungs and my breathing has been wonderful since! 6 fillings, 4 extractions and a root canal to prepare for chemo!! Taking femara daily and just started monthly Zometa and scan showed nodes round lung shrinking, yay! And bones shining brightly which is either progression or healing. We are hoping for healing! I was a very sick chick from all the meds and now I have managed to reduce them I have gotten the nausea under control which Makes for a wonderful life, gosh I feel so much happier. I live for the moment and the longer I can stay relatively well and not on chemo the better. I love having contact with all of you lovely ladies, it is very comforting. Love Gail
Posts.Title: Roll Call 2013 LilSchatzie reader123

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2013 03:52PM Australia wrote: Hello Barbara, Well it is apparently quite common to become incontinent when you have bone cancer. Mine was that I would be thinking i needed to go to the toilet and would be wetting my pants before I got there. It got so bad that one time I stood up and had to go to then and there which was dreadful. When I got to hospital they asked about whether I had been incontinent and put me on a saline drip for a few days and it resolved it thankfully. Also I came home on oxycontinen 40 mg morn and night,anti nausea tabs, etc etc and was sooo sick, dry retching all the time and could not eat. I ran out of oxycontinen on the weekend and could not find my script and thought I will have to last till Monday. Well I had the most shocking diareeha, it would not stop and was bright yellow! I was so ill and when I googled info on what was happening it was that I was going through withdrawal from oxycontinen, which can be like going cold turkey from heroin with the side effects. I decided that was it and reduced the oxycontinen to 20 mg morn and night and have had no nausea tabs since. I would say it's like I went through a detox unintentionally. I had my first Zometa a week ago and feeling nauseous sometimes since and not sure if its the drug or the cancer, but will try and find out. Regards,Gail.

Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Australia wrote: Hi, just wondering if anyone else had cancer to the mediastinum and how they are traveling. I was diagnosed last July after being cancer free for 6 years. It's amazing how I feel now from last year, I was so ill. I was patted on the leg and told I maybe had 3 years and thought I would die within months as I needed a walking frame just to get around. I had a plural effusion and had it drained 3 times before having the talc treatment, which was very successful. l I had been on femara and had an increase in the spine mets so have now nearly finished 4 months of abraxane chemo as well as Zometa. The last ct scan showed spine mets are receding and bone is regrowing and there is no fluid around lung and nodes appear to be inactive! Wonderful news so far! So now I have hope and just hope it is not a temporary period and I get lots more years. I went a bit crazy and spent a lot of money thinking I had no time left and now have realized I could have many years so have stopped spending lol. Love to all, Gail Bc 2006 17 of 25 nodes ca. Lump/chemo/rads. 7/ 2012 mets spine/ribs/pelvis/mediastinal /pl.eff. Femara 3 months progression in spine o abraxane 4 months followed by affinitor/aromasin combo Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2014 04:32PM - edited Jan 21, 2014 04:33PM by Australia last year I terrible pain from spine Mets and was on 40mg oxycontinen am/pm. Had rads which brought wonderful pain relief and over the next 12 months reduced the dosage to 15mg am/pm. I was started on aromasin/afinitor and aft 3months I ended up with blood clots in both lungs and numerous liver lesions. Now I have terrible pain in my spine and have increased my oxycontinen back to 40mg.I am supposed to be going on a cruise 2/2 to New Zealand with my son and am beside myself I will be in pain. This is our first holiday in 12 years and I don't want to cancel but am frightened i will be in pain and was unable to get sickness benefits due to being metastatic. I pushed for an onc visit Thursday, so i hope she has some answers.love Gail

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 09:35PM - edited Mar 2, 2013 09:36PM by Australia Hi Karen, it's Gail from bcaus, I thought now here's a familiar name lol! I have not asked and do not want to google as I know it would be bad. I have a malignant plueral effusion also MOX and find that info on between 4-6 months depressing! I was diagnosed I August last year and feeling great with only Femara shrinking the tumors, so if I believed those stats I would not have much longer to live. We run our own race, everyone's body is different so there is no point in comparing. Live as good as you can in the moment and laugh and eat and drink whatever you want, that's my reality now.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2013 06:12PM - edited Feb 10, 2013 06:16PM by Australia I must admit I have been a lurker and not been actively involved in the forum, but think it its wonderful and very grateful for all who keep it going. I know what you mean as i am actively involved in another forum and have over 7000 posts and because I have been questioning my involvement there recently for the same reasons mentioned here, it has kept me from being so involved In this forum. Sometimes you give and give for little return, but because we get so much out of the friendships formed it s difficult to leave. Losing Angels, people you become close to and then never hear from again and the big personalities that just move one all takes their toll on a forum. We just have to hope its a phase and newbies will step up to keep things going for everyone's benefit, it really is important. Gosh I just saw I have been a member since 2007, that is so pathetic with 4 posts! But I mist admit I have only been on since being diagnosed with mets September last year. I for one will make more of an effort to contribute.
Posts.Title: Anyone else missing that something...... Chickadee K-Lo

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 08:11AM - edited May 6, 2013 08:13AM by Australia I went to a club where I am a member this afternoon and as my hair is thinning and patchy from chemo I brought a Lille black fedora hat with gold beads to wear. I was relaxing playing the pokies when an older man cme up with glass of wine in hand and said" I realise you probably think you look smart or something or are trying to make a statement, but this is a club and you should show courtesy by not wearing a hat!" He was about o walk off having accomplished his belittling of me when I said in a loud voice " excuse me, I wear a hat because I have cancer!" He just studied me and was going to walk off so I repeated myself. He said in a gruff tone " well if that's the case I'm sorry" I told him how rude he was and I did not accept his apology and to leave me alone, but he was a bit drunk and wouldn't. I just kept repeating , go away you rude man and he did. A lady next to me was mortified and had pressed the button for help from staff. When I had to resell the story it opened the flood gates and I could not stop crying. Very embarrassing! The female manager on duty had him evicted from the club which was very nice of her. She said he just didnt get it how rude he had been to me and kept saying " but I said I was sorry!" Apparently he had been banned previously for 4 months for upsetting someone , so I'm glad he was sent home, might give him something to think about. I am tired and washed out from it all, which was to have been a switch off for me to relax.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2014 09:13PM Australia wrote: Hi sham, I now have blood clots in both lungs as well as numerous lesions in liver. Zometa is given as an infusion,like chemo and xgeva is given as an injection. These are purely to strengthen the bone and can go on for years or months, depends on the patient response. I have stopped after a year as my calcium levels are good now. Aromasin is used to stop the body producing estregen and would have no effect on your mums breathing.The radiation would be to ease the bone spots that are painful. As an area can only be radiated once they will save radiation till it hurts. It can bring wonderful relief as can medication such as oxycontinen or endone. I have been on Abraxane chemotherapy and found it was easy on my body with a good reponse,apart from loosing my hair. I went on another chemo that gave me a heap of issues, and now I start abraxane again next week. Hope this helps you, and your mum finds the right chemo and meds . Love Gai
